Filtering CIP data

The first step in exploring student record data is to select the Classification of Instructional Programs (CIP) codes of the programs one wishes to investigate. filter_cip() assists in that selection.

# the cip data are included with midfieldr 
library(midfieldr)
# packages used in the vignette
library(dplyr) 
library(stringr)

Type ?cip for the cip dataset help page.

Basic filtering

With the default arguments, the set of 2-digit codes and names is returned with 48 observations.

filter_cip()
#> # A tibble: 48 x 2
#>    code                                                     name
#>   <chr>                                                    <chr>
#> 1    01 Agriculture/Agricultural Operations and Related Sciences
#> 2    03                       Natural Resources and Conservation
#> 3    04                        Architecture and Related Services
#> 4    05                  Area/Ethnic/Cultural and Gender Studies
#> 5    09           Communications/Journalism and Related Programs
#> 6    10         Communications Technologies and Support Services
#> # ... with 42 more rows

With type = 4 we get the set of 4-digit names and codes with 411 observations.

filter_cip(type = 4)
#> # A tibble: 411 x 2
#>    code                                      name
#>   <chr>                                     <chr>
#> 1  0100                       Agriculture/General
#> 2  0101      Agricultural Business and Management
#> 3  0102                Agricultural Mechanization
#> 4  0103        Agricultural Production Operations
#> 5  0104 Agricultural and Food Products Processing
#> 6  0105 Agricultural and Domestic Animal Services
#> # ... with 405 more rows

With type = 6 we get the set of 6-digit names and codes with 1543 observations.

filter_cip(type = 6)
#> # A tibble: 1,543 x 2
#>     code                                                 name
#>    <chr>                                                <chr>
#> 1 010000                                Agriculture - General
#> 2 010101       Agricultural Business and Management - General
#> 3 010102        Agribusiness/Agricultural Business Operations
#> 4 010103                               Agricultural Economics
#> 5 010104                       Farm/Farm and Ranch Management
#> 6 010105 Agricultural/Farm Supplies Retailing and Wholesaling
#> # ... with 1,537 more rows

Filtering on a 2-digit series number yields one program.

filter_cip(series = "14")
#> # A tibble: 1 x 2
#>    code        name
#>   <chr>       <chr>
#> 1    14 Engineering

The series argument can return more than one series.

filter_cip(series = c("14", "15"))
#> # A tibble: 2 x 2
#>    code                   name
#>   <chr>                  <chr>
#> 1    14            Engineering
#> 2    15 Engineering Technology

Changing to 4-digit codes yields all the 4-digit codes in these series.

filter_cip(type = 4, series = c("14", "15"))
#> # A tibble: 57 x 2
#>    code                                                   name
#>   <chr>                                                  <chr>
#> 1  1401                                    Engineering/General
#> 2  1402   Aerospace/Aeronautical and Astronautical Engineering
#> 3  1403 Agricultural/Biological Engineering and Bioengineering
#> 4  1404                              Architectural Engineering
#> 5  1405                         Biomedical/Medical Engineering
#> 6  1406                       Ceramic Sciences and Engineering
#> # ... with 51 more rows

Predefined groups of programs

For several groups of programs, CIP codes have been collected in predefined character vectors that can be used as the series argument in filter_cip(). Each predefined group is a small data set in midfieldr.

  • Engineering: series_engr
  • Humanities: series_hum
  • Mathematics: series_math
  • Sciences: series_sci
  • Social Sciences: series_socsci

For example, to obtain all 4-digit level Engineering programs,

filter_cip(type = 4, series = series_engr)
#> # A tibble: 40 x 2
#>    code                                                   name
#>   <chr>                                                  <chr>
#> 1  1401                                    Engineering/General
#> 2  1402   Aerospace/Aeronautical and Astronautical Engineering
#> 3  1403 Agricultural/Biological Engineering and Bioengineering
#> 4  1404                              Architectural Engineering
#> 5  1405                         Biomedical/Medical Engineering
#> 6  1406                       Ceramic Sciences and Engineering
#> # ... with 34 more rows

To obtain all 6-digit Engineering,

filter_cip(type = 6, series =  series_engr)
#> # A tibble: 54 x 2
#>     code                                                   name
#>    <chr>                                                  <chr>
#> 1 140101                                  Engineering - General
#> 2 140102                                        Pre-Engineering
#> 3 140201   Aerospace/Aeronautical and Astronautical Engineering
#> 4 140301 Agricultural/Biological Engineering and Bioengineering
#> 5 140401                              Architectural Engineering
#> 6 140501                         Biomedical/Medical Engineering
#> # ... with 48 more rows

To see the CIP codes assigned to these predefined vectors,

series_socsci
#>  [1] "05"   "09"   "13"   "19"   "22"   "25"   "36"   "42"   "43"   "44"  
#> [11] "45"   "3005" "3015" "3020" "3021" "3023" "3026"

To see the names of the programs as well,

cip_socsci <- filter(cip, code %in% series_socsci) 
kable(cip_socsci)
code name
05 Area/Ethnic/Cultural and Gender Studies
09 Communications/Journalism and Related Programs
13 Education
19 Family and Consumer Sciences/Human Sciences
22 Law/Legal Services and Legal Studies
25 Library Science
36 Leisure and Recreational Activities
42 Psychology
43 Protective Services
44 Public Administration and Services
45 Social Sciences
3005 Peace Studies and Conflict Resolution - Multi/Interdisciplinary Studies
3015 Science/Technology and Society - Multi/Interdisciplinary Studies
3020 International/Global Studies - Multi/Interdisciplinary Studies
3021 Holocaust and Related Studies - Multi/Interdisciplinary Studies
3023 Intercultural/Multicultural and Diversity Studies - Multi/Interdisciplinary Studies
3026 Cultural Studies/Critical Theory and Analysis

To locally remove programs from a predefined vector

omit_codes    <- c("3005", "3015")
my_series_socsci <- series_socsci[!series_socsci %in% omit_codes]

# check the result
my_series_socsci
#>  [1] "05"   "09"   "13"   "19"   "22"   "25"   "36"   "42"   "43"   "44"  
#> [11] "45"   "3020" "3021" "3023" "3026"

To locally add programs to a predefined vector

add_codes     <- c("3005", "3015")
my_series_socsci <- c(my_series_socsci, add_codes)

# check the result
my_series_socsci
#>  [1] "05"   "09"   "13"   "19"   "22"   "25"   "36"   "42"   "43"   "44"  
#> [11] "45"   "3020" "3021" "3023" "3026" "3005" "3015"

Filter by name

To filter by name across all levels (2, 4, 6), use the conventional dplyr::filter() function. For example, search for all names that include "techno".

# filter CIP over names, all levels
filter(cip, str_detect(name, fixed("techno", ignore_case = TRUE)))
#> # A tibble: 209 x 2
#>    code                                             name
#>   <chr>                                            <chr>
#> 1    10 Communications Technologies and Support Services
#> 2    15                           Engineering Technology
#> 3    29                            Military Technologies
#> 4    41                 Science Technologies/Technicians
#> 5    47                   Mechanic and Repair Technology
#> 6  0110                      Food Science and Technology
#> # ... with 203 more rows

If we know the initial level and series we want to search, we use filter_cip() or its derivatives and filter the results by name.

For example, to extract Chemical, Civil, Electrical, and Mechanical Engineering codes from the Engineering results, we start by creating a character vector with those terms,

# obtain all Engineering programs using 4-digit codes
engr_cip4 <- filter_cip(4,  series_engr)

# the largest engineering disciplines by numbers employed
big_name <- c("Civil", "Electrical", "Industrial", "Mechanical")
big_name <- str_c(big_name, collapse = "|")

# filter for big names only  
big_engr_cip4 <- engr_cip4 %>% 
    filter(str_detect(name, big_name)) 

big_engr_cip4
#> # A tibble: 4 x 2
#>    code                                                  name
#>   <chr>                                                 <chr>
#> 1  1408                                     Civil Engineering
#> 2  1410 Electrical/Electronics and Communications Engineering
#> 3  1419                                Mechanical Engineering
#> 4  1435                                Industrial Engineering

We could then use these 4-digit codes as a custom series to obtain all the 6-digit data associated with these programs,

# extract the 4-digit codes
custom_series <- big_engr_cip4$code

# filter at the 6-digit level 
big_engr_cip6 <- filter_cip(type = 6, series = custom_series)

kable(big_engr_cip6)
code name
140801 Civil Engineering - General
140802 Geotechnical Engineering
140803 Structural Engineering
140804 Transportation and Highway Engineering
140805 Water Resources Engineering
140899 Civil Engineering - Other
141001 Electrical/Electronics and Communications Engineering
141003 Laser and Optical Engineering
141004 Telecommunications Engineering
141099 Electrical/Electronics and Communications Engineering - Other
141901 Mechanical Engineering
143501 Industrial Engineering

Note that while Civil Engineering (1408) and Electrical Engineering (1410) have a number of 6-digit specialties, Mechanical Engineering (1419) and Industrial Engineering (1435) do not. This does not imply that such specialties do not exist (they do) but that such specialties are not encoded in the CIP dataset.
